title: 114_hr4254
content: The Act is titled the "Freedom for Workers to Seek Opportunity Act" and includes definitions. The Act titled the "Freedom for Workers to Seek Opportunity Act" defines "commerce" and "covenant not to compete" as agreements between an employee and employer that restrict the employee from working for another employer in a specified period, geographical area, or similar work after the enactment of the Act. The Act defines terms such as "employee", "employer", "enterprise", "goods", and "grocery store" according to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. A "grocery store" is an establishment that sells a variety of staple foods for home consumption, including meat, poultry, fish, breads, cereals, vegetables, and fruits. The Act defines terms such as "grocery store employee", "Secretary", and "State" in relation to the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Prohibition on covenants not to compete and agreements restricting grocery store employees' mobility. Prohibition on covenants not to compete with grocery store employees engaged in commerce and notice requirement. Purchase agreements between employers owning grocery stores cannot restrict hiring of each other's employees. SEC. 4. Grocery store employee retention of seniority and benefits after acquisition or merger. An acquiring employer must recognize the seniority of a retained grocery store employee and provide benefits if possible. SEC. 5. Enforcement. The Secretary will handle complaints of violations of specific sections in a similar way to complaints under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Civil fines up to $5,000 per employee may be imposed for violations. When determining fines under this subsection, the Secretary considers the appropriateness of the fine based on the size of the employer and the gravity of the violation.
